nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: Pickup Time
nodes.text: You’re buckling your child into the car seat after pickup. They seem unsettled, glancing out the window.

choices.label: Ask if something feels off today.
choices.text: “Hey, you look a bit quiet. Everything alright?”

choices.label: Talk about the fun plans you have to distract them.
choices.text: You jump into distraction mode: “Guess what? We can watch your favourite movie later!”

choices.label: Stay silent and hope it passes.
choices.text: You decide not to press. Maybe they’re just tired.

nodes.speaker: Child
nodes.title: Confusion
nodes.text: After a few minutes, they speak quietly: “At mom’s house I can stay up as late as I want. But here I can’t. I don’t get it.”

choices.label: Validate the feeling and explain simply.
choices.text: “I hear you. It can be confusing when the rules are different in two homes.”

choices.label: Compare homes and imply the other parent is careless.
choices.text: “Yeah, well… things are more organised here. That’s just how it is.”

choices.label: Ignore the topic and change conversation.
choices.text: “Let’s not talk about that right now — what do you want for dinner?”

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: Deciding What To Say
nodes.text: You’re at a crossroads: keep focusing only on the child, or bring this up with the co-parent too?

choices.label: Focus on the child’s feelings first.
choices.text: You keep the car ride centred on them: “What part feels the hardest?”

choices.label: Immediately plan to confront the co-parent.
choices.text: You think: “We need to fix this tonight. I’ll call as soon as we get home.”

nodes.speaker: Co-Parent
nodes.title: Later That Evening
nodes.text: You send a short message: “Hey, our kid mentioned different bedtime rules. Can we sync up a bit?” The reply comes quickly: “Are you saying I’m doing something wrong?”

choices.label: Reassure them you’re not blaming — focus on the child’s stability.
choices.text: “Not at all. I just want things to feel consistent for them. Maybe we can pick one thing to align on?”

choices.label: Double down on criticism.
choices.text: “Well… it *is* confusing for them. You can’t just let them do whatever.”

choices.label: Drop the topic entirely to keep peace.
choices.text: “Never mind, it’s fine. Forget I asked.”

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: Closing the Scene
nodes.text: Consistency between homes isn’t about identical rules — it’s about safety, predictability, and being able to talk without fear. Tonight, you took one step toward that.
